post.description: Use the People Enrichment endpoint to enrich data for 1 person. Apollo relies on the information you pass via the endpoint's parameters to identify the correct person to enrich. If you provide more information about a person, Apollo is more likely to find a match within its database. By default, this endpoint does not return personal emails or phone numbers. Use the reveal_personal_emails and reveal_phone_number parameters to retrieve emails and phone numbers. Calling this endpoint does consume credits as part of your Apollo pricing plan. This feature is not accessible to Apollo users on free plans.

parameters.name: first_name
parameters.description: The first name of the person. This is typically used in combination with the last_name parameter.

parameters.name: last_name
parameters.description: The last name of the person. This is typically used in combination with the first_name parameter.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The full name of the person. This will typically be a first name and last name separated by a space. If you use this parameter, you do not need to use the first_name and last_name parameters.

parameters.name: email
parameters.description: The email address of the person.

parameters.name: hashed_email
parameters.description: The hashed email of the person. The email should adhere to either the MD5 or SHA-256 hash format.

parameters.name: organization_name
parameters.description: Name of the organization where the person works.

parameters.name: domain
parameters.description: Domain of the organization where the person works.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the person. Each person in the Apollo database is assigned a unique ID. To find IDs, call the People Search endpoint and identify the values for person_id.

parameters.name: linkedin_url
parameters.description: The URL for the person's LinkedIn profile.

parameters.name: reveal_personal_emails
parameters.description: Include personal email addresses in the response. By default, this endpoint does not return personal emails.

parameters.name: reveal_phone_number
parameters.description: Include phone numbers in the response. By default, this endpoint does not return phone numbers. When set to true, a webhook_url parameter is required for phone number delivery.

parameters.name: webhook_url
parameters.description: Webhook URL where Apollo will deliver the phone number data. Required when reveal_phone_number is set to true. The webhook delivery occurs separately, usually several minutes after a successful API request.

post.description: Enrich data for up to 10 people with a single API call

parameters.name: reveal_personal_emails
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to enrich all matched people with personal emails. This potentially consumes credits as part of your Apollo pricing plan. If a person resides in a GDPR-compliant region, Apollo will not reveal their personal email.

parameters.name: reveal_phone_number
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to enrich the data of all matched people with all available phone numbers, including mobile phone numbers. This potentially consumes credits as part of your Apollo pricing plan. If this parameter is set to true, you must enter a webhook URL for the webhook_url parameter.

parameters.name: webhook_url
parameters.description: Required when reveal_phone_number is true. Apollo will asynchronously verify phone numbers and send a JSON response with phone number details to this webhook URL. It can take several minutes for the phone numbers to be delivered.

first_name.description: The first name of the person. This is typically used in combination with the last_name parameter.

last_name.description: The last name of the person. This is typically used in combination with the first_name parameter.

name.description: The full name of the person. This will typically be a first name and last name separated by a space. If you use this parameter, you do not need to use the first_name and last_name parameters.

email.description: The email address of the person.

hashed_email.description: The hashed email of the person. The email should adhere to either the MD5 or SHA-256 hash format.

organization_name.description: The name of the person's employer. This can be the current employer or a previous employer.

domain.description: The domain name for the person's employer. This can be the current employer or a previous employer. Do not include www., the @ symbol, or similar.

id.description: The Apollo ID for the person. Each person in the Apollo database is assigned a unique ID. To find IDs, call the People Search endpoint and identify the values for person_id.

linkedin_url.description: LinkedIn profile URL of the person

details.description: Array of person details to enrich (up to 10 people). Each object should contain identifying information like name, email, organization, or LinkedIn URL.

unique_enriched_records.description: Number of unique records successfully enriched

missing_records.description: Number of records that could not be found

credits_consumed.description: Number of credits consumed for this request

get.summary: Enrich data for a single organization
get.description: Use this endpoint to enrich data for 1 company. Enriched data potentially includes industry information, revenue, employee counts, funding round details, and corporate phone numbers and locations.

parameters.name: domain
parameters.description: The domain name of the organization to enrich (e.g., apollo.io, microsoft.com). Do not include www., http://, or similar prefixes.

post.description: Enrich data for up to 10 companies with a single API call using domain names

parameters.name: domains[]
parameters.description: The domain of each company that you want to enrich. Do not include www., the @ symbol, or similar.

post.description: Search for people in the Apollo database with various filters. Consumes credits and limited to 50,000 records (100 per page, up to 500 pages). Not accessible to free plan users.

parameters.name: person_titles[]
parameters.description: Job titles held by the people you want to find. For a person to be included in search results, they only need to match 1 of the job titles you add. Adding more job titles expands your search results. Results also include job titles with the same terms, even if they are not exact matches. Use in combination with person_seniorities[] parameter to find people based on specific job functions and seniority levels.

parameters.name: include_similar_titles
parameters.description: Determines whether people with job titles similar to the titles you define in the person_titles[] parameter are returned in the response. Set to false when using person_titles[] to return only strict matches for job titles.

parameters.name: q_keywords
parameters.description: A string of words over which we want to filter the results

parameters.name: person_locations[]
parameters.description: The location where people live. You can search across cities, US states, and countries. To find people based on the headquarters locations of their current employer, use the organization_locations parameter.

parameters.name: person_seniorities[]
parameters.description: The job seniority that people hold within their current employer. For a person to be included in search results, they only need to match 1 of the seniorities you add. Adding more seniorities expands your search results. Searches only return results based on their current job title. Use this parameter in combination with the person_titles[] parameter to find people based on specific job functions and seniority levels.

parameters.name: organization_locations[]
parameters.description: The location of the company headquarters for a person's current employer. You can search across cities, US states, and countries. If a company has several office locations, results are still based on the headquarters location. To find people based on their personal location, use the person_locations parameter.

parameters.name: q_organization_domains_list[]
parameters.description: The domain name for the person's employer. This can be the current employer or a previous employer. Do not include www., the @ symbol, or similar. This parameter accepts up to 1,000 domains in a single request.

parameters.name: contact_email_status[]
parameters.description: The email statuses for the people you want to find. You can add multiple statuses to expand your search.

parameters.name: organization_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the companies (employers) you want to include in your search results. Each company in the Apollo database is assigned a unique ID. To find IDs, call the Organization Search endpoint and identify the values for organization_id.

parameters.name: organization_num_employees_ranges[]
parameters.description: The number range of employees working for the person's current company. This enables you to find people based on the headcount of their employer. You can add multiple ranges to expand your search results. Each range you add needs to be a string, with the upper and lower numbers of the range separated only by a comma.

parameters.name: revenue_range[min]
parameters.description: The minimum revenue the person's current employer generates. Use this parameter in combination with revenue_range[max] to set a revenue range. Do not enter currency symbols, commas, or decimal points in the figure.

parameters.name: revenue_range[max]
parameters.description: The maximum revenue the person's current employer generates. Use this parameter in combination with revenue_range[min] to set a revenue range. Do not enter currency symbols, commas, or decimal points in the figure.

parameters.name: currently_using_all_of_technology_uids[]
parameters.description: Find people based on all of the technologies their current employer uses. Apollo supports filtering by 1,500+ technologies. Use underscores (_) to replace spaces and periods for the technologies listed in the CSV file.

parameters.name: currently_using_any_of_technology_uids[]
parameters.description: Find people based on any of the technologies their current employer uses. Apollo supports filtering by 1,500+ technologies. Use underscores (_) to replace spaces and periods for the technologies listed in the CSV file.

parameters.name: currently_not_using_any_of_technology_uids[]
parameters.description: Exclude people from your search based on any of the technologies their current employer uses. Apollo supports filtering by 1,500+ technologies. Use underscores (_) to replace spaces and periods for the technologies listed in the CSV file.

parameters.name: q_organization_job_titles[]
parameters.description: The job titles that are listed in active job postings at the person's current employer.

parameters.name: organization_job_locations[]
parameters.description: The locations of the jobs being actively recruited by the person's employer.

parameters.name: organization_num_jobs_range[min]
parameters.description: The minimum number of job postings active at the person's current employer. Use this parameter in combination with organization_num_jobs_range[max] to set a job postings range.

parameters.name: organization_num_jobs_range[max]
parameters.description: The maximum number of job postings active at the person's current employer. Use this parameter in combination with organization_num_jobs_range[min] to set a job postings range.

parameters.name: organization_job_posted_at_range[min]
parameters.description: The earliest date when jobs were posted by the person's current employer. Use this parameter in combination with organization_job_posted_at_range[max] to set a date range for when jobs posted.

parameters.name: organization_job_posted_at_range[max]
parameters.description: The latest date when jobs were posted by the person's current employer. Use this parameter in combination with organization_job_posted_at_range[min] to set a date range for when jobs posted.

parameters.name: organization_industries[]
parameters.description: Industries to filter organizations by

parameters.name: organization_keywords[]
parameters.description: Keywords related to organizations

parameters.name: prospected_by_current_team[]
parameters.description: Filter by whether person was prospected by current team

parameters.name: stages[]
parameters.description: Sales stages to filter by

parameters.name: account_stages[]
parameters.description: Account stages to filter by

parameters.name: departments[]
parameters.description: Departments to filter by

parameters.name: subdepartments[]
parameters.description: Subdepartments to filter by

parameters.name: functions[]
parameters.description: Job functions to filter by

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results for navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of search results that should be returned for each page. Limiting the number of results per page improves the endpoint's performance. Use the page parameter to search the different pages of data.

post.description: Find companies in the Apollo database using various filters. This endpoint consumes credits and requires a paid Apollo plan. Limited to 50,000 records (100 per page, up to 500 pages).

parameters.name: organization_num_employees_ranges[]
parameters.description: The number range of employees working for the company. This enables you to find companies based on headcount. You can add multiple ranges to expand your search results. Each range you add needs to be a string, with the upper and lower numbers of the range separated only by a comma. Examples: 1,10; 250,500; 10000,20000

parameters.name: organization_locations[]
parameters.description: The location of the company headquarters. You can search across cities, US states, and countries. If a company has several office locations, results are still based on the headquarters location. For example, if you search chicago but a company's HQ location is in boston, any Boston-based companies will not appear in your search results, even if they match other parameters. To exclude companies based on location, use the organization_not_locations parameter. Examples: texas; tokyo; spain

parameters.name: organization_not_locations[]
parameters.description: Exclude companies from search results based on the location of the company headquarters. You can use cities, US states, and countries as locations to exclude. This parameter is useful for ensuring you do not prospect in an undesirable territory. For example, if you use ireland as a value, no Ireland-based companies will appear in your search results. Examples: minnesota; ireland; seoul

parameters.name: revenue_range[min]
parameters.description: Search for organizations based on their revenue. Use this parameter to set the lower range of organization revenue. Use the revenue_range[max] parameter to set the upper range of revenue. Do not enter currency symbols, commas, or decimal points in the figure. Example: 300000

parameters.name: revenue_range[max]
parameters.description: Search for organizations based on their revenue. Use this parameter to set the upper range of organization revenue. Use the revenue_range[min] parameter to set the lower range of revenue. Do not enter currency symbols, commas, or decimal points in the figure. Example: 50000000

parameters.name: currently_using_any_of_technology_uids[]
parameters.description: Find organizations based on the technologies they currently use. Apollo supports filtering by 1,500+ technologies. Apollo calculates technologies data from multiple sources. This data is updated regularly. Check out the full list of supported technologies by downloading this CSV file. Use underscores (_) to replace spaces and periods for the technologies listed in the CSV file. Examples: salesforce; google_analytics; wordpress_org

parameters.name: q_organization_keyword_tags[]
parameters.description: Filter search results based on keywords associated with companies. For example, you can enter mining as a value to return only companies that have an association with the mining industry. Examples: mining; sales strategy; consulting

parameters.name: q_organization_name
parameters.description: Filter search results to include a specific company name. If the value you enter for this parameter does not match with a company's name, the company will not appear in search results, even if it matches other parameters. Partial matches are accepted. For example, if you filter by the value marketing, a company called NY Marketing Unlimited would still be eligible as a search result, but NY Market Analysis would not be eligible. Example: apollo or mining

parameters.name: organization_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the companies you want to include in your search results. Each company in the Apollo database is assigned a unique ID. To find IDs, identify the values for organization_id when you call this endpoint. Example: 5e66b6381e05b4008c8331b8

parameters.name: latest_funding_amount_range[min]
parameters.description: The minimum amount the company received with its most recent funding round. Use this parameter in combination with latest_funding_amount_range[max] to set a monetary range for the company's most recent funding round. Do not enter currency symbols, commas, or decimal points in the figure. Examples: 5000000; 15000000

parameters.name: latest_funding_amount_range[max]
parameters.description: The maximum amount the company received with its most recent funding round. Use this parameter in combination with latest_funding_amount_range[min] to set a monetary range for the company's most recent funding round. Do not enter currency symbols, commas, or decimal points in the figure. Examples: 5000000; 15000000

parameters.name: total_funding_range[min]
parameters.description: The minimum amount the company received during all of its funding rounds combined. Use this parameter in combination with total_funding_range[max] to set a monetary range for all of the company's funding rounds. Do not enter currency symbols, commas, or decimal points in the figure. Examples: 50000000; 350000000

parameters.name: total_funding_range[max]
parameters.description: The maximum amount the company received during all of its funding rounds combined. Use this parameter in combination with total_funding_range[min] to set a monetary range for all of the company's funding rounds. Do not enter currency symbols, commas, or decimal points in the figure. Examples: 50000000; 350000000

parameters.name: latest_funding_date_range[min]
parameters.description: The earliest date when the company received its most recent funding round. Use this parameter in combination with latest_funding_date_range[max] to set a date range for when the company received its most recent funding round. Example: 2025-07-25

parameters.name: latest_funding_date_range[max]
parameters.description: The latest date when the company received its most recent funding round. Use this parameter in combination with latest_funding_date_range[min] to set a date range for when the company received its most recent funding round. Example: 2025-09-25

parameters.name: q_organization_job_titles[]
parameters.description: The job titles that are listed in active job postings at the company. Examples: sales manager; research analyst

parameters.name: organization_job_locations[]
parameters.description: The locations of the jobs being actively recruited by the company. Examples: atlanta; japan

parameters.name: organization_num_jobs_range[min]
parameters.description: The minimum number of job postings active at the company. Use this parameter in combination with organization_num_jobs_range[max] to set a job postings range. Examples: 50; 500

parameters.name: organization_num_jobs_range[max]
parameters.description: The maximum number of job postings active at the company. Use this parameter in combination with organization_num_jobs_range[min] to set a job postings range. Examples: 50; 500

parameters.name: organization_job_posted_at_range[min]
parameters.description: The earliest date when jobs were posted by the company. Use this parameter in combination with organization_job_posted_at_range[max] to set a date range for when jobs posted. Example: 2025-07-25

parameters.name: organization_job_posted_at_range[max]
parameters.description: The latest date when jobs were posted by the company. Use this parameter in combination with organization_job_posted_at_range[min] to set a date range for when jobs posted. Example: 2025-09-25

parameters.name: q_organization_domains
parameters.description: The domain names of organizations to search for

parameters.name: organization_industry_tag_ids
parameters.description: Industry tag IDs to filter organizations by industry

parameters.name: organization_founded_year_ranges
parameters.description: Founded year ranges for organizations

parameters.name: organization_keywords
parameters.description: Keywords to search in organization descriptions

parameters.name: organization_technology_names
parameters.description: Technology names used by organizations

parameters.name: organization_publicly_traded_status
parameters.description: Public/private status of organizations

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results for navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint. Example: 4

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of search results that should be returned for each page. Limiting the number of results per page improves the endpoint's performance. Use the page parameter to search the different pages of data. Example: 10

get.description: Retrieve current job postings for a specific organization. Limited to 10,000 records.

parameters.name: organization_id
parameters.description: The organization ID of the company for which you want to find job postings. Each company in the Apollo database is assigned a unique ID. To find IDs, call the Organization Search endpoint and identify the values for organization_id.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results for navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of search results that should be returned for each page. Limiting the number of results per page improves the endpoint's performance. Use the page parameter to search the different pages of data.

get.description: Retrieve complete details about an organization in the Apollo database

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the organization that you want to research. To find organization IDs, call the Organization Search endpoint and identify the organizaton_id value for the organization.

403.description: Unauthorized - Master API key required

post.description: Find news articles related to companies in the Apollo database. Several filters are available to help narrow your search. This endpoint consumes credits as part of your Apollo pricing plan and is not accessible to Apollo users on free plans.

parameters.name: organization_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the companies you want to include in your search results. Each company in the Apollo database is assigned a unique ID. To find IDs, call the Organization Search endpoint and identify the values for organization_id.

parameters.name: categories[]
parameters.description: Filter your search to include only certain categories or sub-categories of news. Use the News search filter for companies within Apollo to uncover all possible categories and sub-categories.

parameters.name: published_at[min]
parameters.description: Set the lower bound of the date range you want to search. Use this parameter in combination with the published_at[max] parameter. This date should fall before the published_at[max] date. The date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: published_at[max]
parameters.description: Set the upper bound of the date range you want to search. Use this parameter in combination with the published_at[min] parameter. This date should fall after the published_at[min] date. The date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results for navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of Apollo data records that you want to retrieve per page. Use this parameter in combination with the page parameter to make search results navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint. Maximum value is 100.

403.description: Feature not available for free plan users

post.description: Add a new account to your team's Apollo account. In Apollo terminology, an account is a company that your team has explicitly added to your database. Apollo does not apply deduplication processes when you create a new account via the API. If your entry has the same name, domain, or other details as an existing account, Apollo will create a new account instead of updating the existing account. To update an existing account, use the Update an Account endpoint instead. This endpoint requires a master API key.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Name the account that you are creating. This should be a human-readable name.

parameters.name: domain
parameters.description: The domain name for the account. Do not include www. or similar.

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The ID for the account owner within your team's Apollo account. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: account_stage_id
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the account stage to which you want to assign the account. Call the List Account Stages endpoint to retrieve a list of all the account stage IDs available in your Apollo account. If you do not specify the account stage, Apollo automatically assigns the account to a stage as determined by your team's Apollo account.

parameters.name: phone
parameters.description: The primary phone number for the account. This can be the phone number for the corporate headquarters, a branch location, or a direct dial to the primary point of contact for the account. Apollo sanitizes phone numbers, so you can enter them in any format.

parameters.name: raw_address
parameters.description: The corporate location for the account. This can include a city, US state, and country. Apollo matches the location you provide to the most applicable pre-defined location.

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required. Refer to Create API Keys documentation to learn how to create a master API key.

put.description: Update existing accounts in your team's Apollo account

parameters.name: account_id
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the account that you want to update. To find account IDs, call the Search for Accounts endpoint and identify the id value for the contact.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Update the account's name. This should be a human-readable name.

parameters.name: domain
parameters.description: Update the domain name for the account. Do not include www. or similar.

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The ID for the account owner within your team's Apollo account. Enter a different ID to update the owner of the account. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: account_stage_id
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the account stage to which you want to assign the account. Enter a different ID to update the account stage. Call the List Account Stages endpoint to retrieve a list of all the account stage IDs available in your Apollo account.

parameters.name: raw_address
parameters.description: Update the corporate location for the account. This can include a city, US state, and country. Apollo matches the location you provide to the most applicable pre-defined location.

parameters.name: phone
parameters.description: Update the primary phone number for the account. This can be the phone number for the corporate headquarters, a branch location, or a direct dial to the primary point of contact for the account. Apollo sanitizes phone numbers, so you can enter them in any format.

403.description: Unauthorized - Master API key required

post.description: Use the Search for Accounts endpoint to search for the account that have been added to your team's Apollo account. In Apollo terminology, an account is a company that your team has explicitly added to your database. This endpoint only returns accounts in the search results. To search for companies in the Apollo database, call the Organization Search endpoint. To protect Apollo's performance for all users, this endpoint has a display limit of 50,000 records (100 records per page, up to 500 pages). Add more filters to narrow your search results as much as possible. This limitation does not restrict your access to Apollo's database; you just need to access the data in batches. This feature is not accessible to Apollo users on free plans.

parameters.name: q_organization_name
parameters.description: Add keywords to narrow the search of the accounts in your team's Apollo account. Keywords should directly match at least part of an account's name. For example, searching the keyword marketing might return the result NY Marketing Unlimited, but not NY Market Analysts. This parameter only searches account names, not other account fields.

apollo.summary: Search for accounts with 'apollo' in the name

microsoft.summary: Search for accounts with 'microsoft' in the name

marketing.summary: Search for accounts with 'marketing' in the name

parameters.name: account_stage_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the account stages that you want to include in your search results. If you add multiple account stages, Apollo will include all accounts that match any of the stages, along with the other parameters, in the search results. Call the List Account Stages endpoint to retrieve a list of all the account stage IDs available in your Apollo account.

parameters.name: sort_by_field
parameters.description: Sort the matching accounts by one of the following options: account_last_activity_date (The most recent activity date recorded first), account_created_at (The most recently created first), account_updated_at (The most recently updated first).

parameters.name: sort_ascending
parameters.description: Set to true to sort the matching contacts in ascending order. This parameter must be used with sort_by_field. Otherwise, the sorting logic is not applied.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results for navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of search results that should be returned for each page. Limiting the number of results per page improves the endpoint's performance. Use the page parameter to search the different pages of data.

get.description: Retrieve details for an existing account in your team's Apollo database

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the account that you want to retrieve. To find account IDs, call the Search for Accounts endpoint and identify the id value for the account.

403.description: Invalid API key or insufficient permissions

post.summary: Update Account Stage for Multiple Accounts
post.description: Update the account stage for several accounts in your team's Apollo account

parameters.name: account_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the account that you want to update. To find account IDs, call the Search for Accounts endpoint and identify the id value for the account.

parameters.name: account_stage_id
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the account stage to which you want to assign the accounts. Call the List Account Stages endpoint to retrieve a list of all the account stage IDs available in your Apollo account.

id.description: The Apollo ID of the updated account

account_stage_id.description: The Apollo ID of the account stage assigned to the account

accounts.description: Array of updated accounts with their IDs and new account stage IDs

403.description: Invalid API key or insufficient permissions

post.summary: Update Account Owner for Multiple Accounts
post.description: Assign multiple accounts to a different user in your team's Apollo account

parameters.name: account_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the account that you want to assign to an owner. To find account IDs, call the Search for Accounts endpoint and identify the id value for the account.

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The ID for the account owner within your team's Apollo account. This user will be assigned ownership of the accounts. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

id.description: The Apollo ID of the updated account

owner_id.description: The Apollo ID of the new account owner

crm_owner_id.description: The CRM owner ID, if applicable

accounts.description: Array of updated accounts with their IDs and new owner information

403.description: Invalid API key or insufficient permissions

get.description: Retrieve the IDs for the available account stages in your team's Apollo account

200.description: List of account stages retrieved successfully

id.description: The Apollo ID of the account stage

team_id.description: The team ID associated with the account stage

display_name.description: The display name of the account stage

name.description: The name of the account stage

display_order.description: The display order of the account stage

default_exclude_for_leadgen.description: Whether this stage is excluded from lead generation by default

category.description: The category of the account stage

is_meeting_set.description: Whether a meeting is set for this stage

account_stages.description: Array of account stages available in your Apollo account

post.description: Add a new contact to your team's Apollo account. Note: Does not apply deduplication - will create new contact even if details match existing ones.

put.description: Update existing contact details in your team's Apollo account

parameters.name: contact_id
parameters.description: ID of the contact to update

post.description: Search for contacts in your team's Apollo account. Limited to 50,000 records (100 per page, up to 500 pages).

parameters.name: q_keywords
parameters.description: Add keywords to narrow the search of the contacts in your team's Apollo account. Keywords can include combinations of names, job titles, employers (company names), and email addresses.
parameters.example: tim zheng; senior research analyst; microsoft

parameters.name: contact_stage_ids
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the contact stages that you want to include in your search results. If you add multiple contact stages, Apollo will include all contacts that match any of the stages, along with the other parameters, in the search results. Call the List Contact Stages endpoint to retrieve a list of all the contact stage IDs available in your Apollo account.

parameters.name: sort_by_field
parameters.description: Sort the matching contacts by one of the following options: contact_last_activity_date (The most recent activity date recorded first), contact_email_last_opened_at (The most recent email opened date first), contact_email_last_clicked_at (The most recent email clicked first), contact_created_at (The most recently created first), contact_updated_at (The most recently updated first).

parameters.name: sort_ascending
parameters.description: Set to true to sort the matching contacts in ascending order. This parameter must be used with sort_by_field. Otherwise, the sorting logic is not applied.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of search results that should be returned for each page. Limiting the number of results per page improves the endpoint's performance. Use the page parameter to search the different pages of data.

200.description: List of contacts matching search criteria

post.summary: Update Contact Stage for Multiple Contacts
post.description: Update the contact stage for multiple contacts simultaneously

parameters.name: contact_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the contacts that you want to update. Must be passed using bracket notation (e.g., contact_ids[]=id1 for one contact, or contact_ids[]=id1&contact_ids[]=id2 for multiple). To find contact IDs, call the Search for Contacts endpoint and identify the id value for the contact.

parameters.name: contact_stage_id
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the contact stage to which you want to assign the contacts. Call the List Contact Stages endpoint to retrieve a list of all the contact stage IDs available in your Apollo account.

error.example: Parameters misconfigured. contact_ids must be an array. You are passing String

post.summary: Update Contact Owner for Multiple Contacts
post.description: Use the Update Contact Owner for Multiple Contacts endpoint to assign multiple contacts to a different user in your team's Apollo account. To update more than the contact's owner, such as job titles or contact details, use the Update a Contact endpoint instead.

parameters.name: contact_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the contacts that you want assign to an owner. Must be passed using bracket notation (e.g., contact_ids[]=id1 for one contact, or contact_ids[]=id1&contact_ids[]=id2 for multiple). To find contact IDs, call the Search for Contacts endpoint and identify the id value for the contact.

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The ID for the contact owner within your team's Apollo account. This user will be assigned ownership of the contacts. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

get.description: Use the List Contact Stages endpoint to retrieve the IDs for the available contact stages in your team's Apollo account. Contact stage IDs can be used to update individual contacts and update the contact stages for multiple contacts via the Apollo API.

post.description: Use the Create Deal endpoint to create new deals for an Apollo account. Deals enable you to track account activity, including monetary values of a deal, deal owners, and deal stages. To update existing deals in your Apollo account, use the Update Deal endpoint instead. This endpoint requires a master API key.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Name the deal you are creating. This should be a human-readable name.

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The ID for the deal owner within your team's Apollo account. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: account_id
parameters.description: The ID for the account within your Apollo instance. This is the company that you are targeting as part of the deal being created. Each company in the Apollo database is assigned a unique ID. To find IDs, call the Organization Search endpoint and identify the values for organization_id.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The monetary value of the deal being created. Do not enter commas or currency symbols for the value. The currency is automatically populated by the settings within your Apollo account. Commas are not accepted and result in the deal amount being left blank.

parameters.name: opportunity_stage_id
parameters.description: The ID for the deal stage within your team's Apollo account. Each deal stage is assigned a unique ID. To find deal stage IDs, call the List Deal Stages endpoint and identify the value for id for each stage.

parameters.name: closed_date
parameters.description: The estimated close date for the deal. This can be a future or past date. The date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required

get.description: Use the List All Deals endpoint to retrieve every deal that has been created for your team's Apollo account. This endpoint requires a master API key. This feature is not accessible to Apollo users on free plans.

parameters.name: sort_by_field
parameters.description: Sort the deals by one of the following options: amount (largest deal values first), is_closed (deals that have been closed first), is_won (deals that have been won first)

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of search results that should be returned for each page. Limiting the number of results per page improves the endpoint's performance. Use the page parameter to search the different pages of data.

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required or free plan limitation

get.description: Use the View Deal endpoint to retrieve complete details about a deal within your team's Apollo account. Deal information can include the ID of the deal owner, the monetary value of the deal, the deal stage, and general details about the account. This endpoint requires a master API key.

parameters.name: opportunity_id
parameters.description: The ID for the deal you want to view. Each deal in the Apollo database is assigned a unique ID. To find deal IDs, call the List All Deals endpoint and identify the value for id for the desired deal.

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required

patch.description: Use the Update Deal endpoint to update the details of existing deals within your team's Apollo account. Deals enable you to track account activity, including monetary values of a deal, deal owners, and deal stages. To create new deals in your Apollo account, use the Create Deal endpoint instead. This endpoint requires a master API key.

parameters.name: opportunity_id
parameters.description: The ID for the deal you want to update. Each deal in the Apollo database is assigned a unique ID. To find deal IDs, call the List All Deals endpoint and identify the value for id for the desired deal.

parameters.name: owner_id
parameters.description: The ID for the deal owner within your team's Apollo account. Enter a different ID to update the owner of the deal. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: Update the name of the deal. This should be a human-readable name.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The monetary value of the deal. Enter a different value to update the deal amount. Do not enter commas or currency symbols for the value. The currency is automatically populated by the settings within your Apollo account. Commas are not accepted and result in the deal amount being left blank.

parameters.name: opportunity_stage_id
parameters.description: The ID for the deal stage within your team's Apollo account. Enter a different ID to update the deal stage. Each deal stage is assigned a unique ID. To find deal stage IDs, call the List Deal Stages endpoint and identify the value for id for each stage.

parameters.name: closed_date
parameters.description: Update the estimated close date for the deal. This can be a future or past date. The date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: is_closed
parameters.description: Set the value to true to update the status of the deal to closed.

parameters.name: is_won
parameters.description: Set the value to true to update the status of the deal to won.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: Update the source of the deal. By default, deals created via Apollo APIs have a source of api.

parameters.name: account_id
parameters.description: The ID for the account within your Apollo instance. Enter a different ID to update the company associated with the deal. Each company in the Apollo database is assigned a unique ID. To find IDs, call the Organization Search endpoint and identify the values for organization_id.

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required

get.description: Use the List Deal Stages endpoint to retrieve information about every deal stage that is available in your team's Apollo account. The id value for each deal stage can be used to set the stage when creating a deal or updating a deal via the Apollo API. This endpoint requires a master API key.

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required

post.description: Use the Search for Sequences endpoint to search for the sequences that have been created for your team's Apollo account. This endpoint requires a master API key. If you attempt to call the endpoint without a master key, you will receive a 403 response. This feature is not accessible to Apollo users on free plans.

parameters.name: q_name
parameters.description: Add keywords to narrow the search of the sequences in your team's Apollo account. Keywords should directly match at least part of a sequence's name. For example, searching the keyword marketing might return the result NY Marketing Sequence, but not NY Marketer Conference 2025 attendees. This parameter only searches sequence names, not other sequence fields.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results for navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of search results that should be returned for each page. Limiting the number of results per page improves the endpoint's performance. Use the page parameter to search the different pages of data.

200.description: List of sequences matching search criteria

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required or free plan limitation

post.description: Use the Add Contacts to a Sequence endpoint to add contacts to the existing sequences in your team's Apollo account. In Apollo terminology, a contact is a person that your team has explicitly added to your database. Only contacts can be added to sequences. To enrich a person's data, call the People Enrichment endpoint. Then, to add the person as a contact in your database, call the Create a Contact endpoint. This endpoint requires a master API key. If you attempt to call the endpoint without a master key, you will receive a 403 response.

parameters.name: sequence_id
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the sequence to which you want to add contacts. To find sequence IDs, call the Search for Sequences endpoint and identify the id value for the sequence.

parameters.name: emailer_campaign_id
parameters.description: The same ID as the sequence_id.

parameters.name: send_email_from_email_account_id
parameters.description: The Apollo ID for the email account that you want to use to send emails to the contacts you are adding to the sequence. To find email account IDs, call the Get a List of Email Accounts endpoint and identify the id value for the email account.

parameters.name: send_email_from_email_address
parameters.description: Optional specific email address to send from within the email account.

parameters.name: sequence_no_email
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to add contacts to the sequence even if they do not have an email address.

parameters.name: sequence_unverified_email
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to add contacts to the sequence if they have an unverified email address.

parameters.name: sequence_job_change
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to add contacts to the sequence even if they have recently changed jobs.

parameters.name: sequence_active_in_other_campaigns
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to add contacts to the sequence even if they have been added to other sequences. This parameter does not differentiate between active and paused sequences.

parameters.name: sequence_finished_in_other_campaigns
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to add contacts to the sequence if they have been marked as finished in another sequence.

parameters.name: sequence_same_company_in_same_campaign
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to add contacts to the sequence even if other contacts from the same company are already in the sequence.

parameters.name: contacts_without_ownership_permission
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to add contacts even if you don't have ownership permission for them.

parameters.name: add_if_in_queue
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to add contacts even if they are currently in the queue for processing.

parameters.name: contact_verification_skipped
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to skip contact verification during the addition process.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID for the user in your team's Apollo account. This is the user taking the action to add contacts to a sequence. When the sequence is updated, the activity log shows the user that added the contacts. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: status
parameters.description: Initial status for added contacts. When set to paused along with auto_unpause_at, enables scheduled addition of contacts.

parameters.name: auto_unpause_at
parameters.description: DateTime when paused contacts should be automatically unpaused. Must be used with status=paused. Format: ISO 8601 datetime string.

parameters.name: contact_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the contacts that you want to add to the sequence. To find contact IDs, call the Search for Contacts endpoint and identify the id value for the contact. Note: Either contact_ids[] or label_names[] must be provided.

parameters.name: label_names[]
parameters.description: Alternative to contact_ids[]. Array of label names to identify contacts to add to the sequence. Contacts with these labels will be added to the sequence. Note: Either contact_ids[] or label_names[] must be provided.

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required

post.summary: Update Contact Status in a Sequence
post.description: Use the Update Contact Status in a Sequence endpoint to either mark contacts as having finished a sequence, or to remove them from a sequence entirely. This endpoint requires a master API key. If you attempt to call the endpoint without a master key, you will receive a 403 response.

parameters.name: emailer_campaign_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the sequences that you want to update. If you add multiple sequences, you will update the status of the contacts across the chosen sequences. To find sequence IDs, call the Search for Sequences endpoint and identify the id value for the sequence.

parameters.name: contact_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the contacts in the sequences. These are the contacts whose sequence status you want to update. To find contact IDs, call the Search for Contacts endpoint and identify the id value for the contact.

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: Choose 1 of the following options to update the sequence status of the contacts: mark_as_finished (Mark the contacts as having finished the sequence), remove (Remove the contacts from the sequence), stop (Indicate that the contacts progress in the sequence has halted).

200.description: Contact status successfully updated in sequence

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required

error.example: This endpoint requires a master API key
Invalid contact IDs or status parameter

get.description: Use the Search for Outreach Emails endpoint to find emails that your team has created and sent as part of Apollo sequences. To protect Apollo's performance for all users, this endpoint has a display limit of 50,000 records (100 records per page, up to 500 pages). Add more filters to narrow your search results as much as possible. This endpoint requires a master API key and is not accessible to Apollo users on free plans.

parameters.name: emailer_message_stats[]
parameters.description: Find emails based on their current status, such as whether they were delivered or opened. You can add multiple statuses.

parameters.name: emailer_message_reply_classes[]
parameters.description: Find emails based on the response sentiment of the recipient. This can include the recipient expressing interest in meeting or having a follow-up question. You can add multiple values.

parameters.name: user_ids[]
parameters.description: Find emails sent by specific users in your team's Apollo account. You can add multiple users. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: email_account_id_and_aliases
parameters.description: Filter emails by email account ID and aliases.

parameters.name: emailer_campaign_ids[]
parameters.description: Search for emails that are included in specific sequences in your Apollo account. You can search multiple sequences. Any sequence not included in this parameter will be exclude from search results. To find sequence IDs, call the Search for Sequences endpoint and identify the id value for the sequence.

parameters.name: not_emailer_campaign_ids[]
parameters.description: Exclude emails from specific sequences in your Apollo account. You can exclude multiple sequences. Any sequence not excluded using this parameter will be included in search results. To find sequence IDs, call the Search for Sequences endpoint and identify the id value for the sequence.

parameters.name: emailer_message_date_range_mode
parameters.description: Use this parameter in combination with the emailerMessageDateRange[max] and emailerMessageDateRange[min] parameters. Find emails based on due_at (When emails are scheduled to be delivered) or completed_at (When emails were delivered).

parameters.name: emailerMessageDateRange[max]
parameters.description: Set the upper bound of the date range you want to search. Use this parameter in combination with the emailerMessageDateRange[min] and emailer_message_date_range_mode parameters. This date should fall after the emailerMessageDateRange[min] date. The date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: emailerMessageDateRange[min]
parameters.description: Set the lower bound of the date range you want to search. Use this parameter in combination with the emailerMessageDateRange[max] and emailer_message_date_range_mode parameters. This date should fall before the emailerMessageDateRange[max] date. The date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: not_sent_reason_cds[]
parameters.description: Find emails based on the reason they were not sent. You can add multiple values.

parameters.name: q_keywords
parameters.description: Add keywords to narrow the search of the emails in your team's Apollo account. Keywords should directly match at least part of an email's content. For example, searching the keyword James might return emails that were sent by James Smith.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results for navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of search results that should be returned for each page. Limiting the number of results per page improves the endpoint's performance. Use the page parameter to search the different pages of data.

breadcrumbs.description: Array of applied filters for navigation

emailer_steps.description: Array of sequence steps related to the emails

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required or not available on free plans

error.example: This endpoint requires a master API key and is not available on free plans

get.description: Use the Check Email Stats endpoint to review the complete details for an email sent as part of an Apollo sequence. This includes the contents of the emails, stats related to the email such as opens and clicks, and details about the contact that received the email. This endpoint requires a master API key. This feature is not accessible to Apollo users on free plans.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the emailer message to retrieve stats for

activities.description: Array of activities related to this email

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required or not available on free plan

post.description: Use the Create a Task endpoint to create tasks in Apollo for you and your team. Tasks help track the upcoming actions you need to take, such as emailing or calling a contact. This endpoint currently only returns true as a response. Apollo does not apply deduplication processes when you create a new task via the API. This endpoint requires a master API key.

parameters.name: user_id
parameters.description: The ID for the task owner within your team's Apollo account. This is the user that will take action on the contacts. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: contact_ids[]
parameters.description: The Apollo IDs for the contacts that you want to be on the receiving end of the action. If you add multiple contact IDs, individual tasks will be created for each contact using the same task type, due date, and other details.

parameters.name: priority
parameters.description: Assign a priority to the task you are creating

parameters.name: due_at
parameters.description: The full date and time when the task will be due. Should adhere to ISO 8601 date-time format. Apollo uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) by default.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: Set the task to be one of the available task types. This enables the task owner to know the type of action they need to take.

parameters.name: status
parameters.description: The status of the task being created. For future-facing tasks, use 'scheduled'. For completed tasks, use 'completed' or 'archived'.

parameters.name: note
parameters.description: Add a description for the task. This should be a human-readable message providing the task owner with more context on the action they need to take.
parameters.example: This contact expressed interest in the Sequences feature specifically. Be prepared to discuss.

schema.description: Returns true when task is created successfully

403.description: Master API key required or feature not available for free plan users

post.description: Use the Search for Tasks endpoint to find tasks that your team has created in Apollo. To protect Apollo's performance for all users, this endpoint has a display limit of 50,000 records (100 records per page, up to 500 pages). Add more filters to narrow your search results as much as possible. This endpoint requires a master API key.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of search results that should be returned for each page. Limiting the number of results per page improves the endpoint's performance. Use the page parameter to search the different pages of data.

parameters.name: sort_by_field
parameters.description: Sort the tasks by one of the following options: task_due_at (most future-dated first), task_priority (highest priority first)

parameters.name: open_factor_names[]
parameters.description: Enter task_types for this parameter to return a count of tasks by task type. When used, the response includes a 'task_types': [] array with a 'count' value for each task type.

403.description: Master API key required or feature not available for free plan users

post.description: Use the Create Call Records endpoint to log calls in Apollo that were made using outside systems such as Orum or Nooks. This endpoint can only be used create call records, not to dial prospects. This endpoint requires a master API key. If you attempt to call the endpoint without a master key, you will receive a 403 response.

parameters.name: logged
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to create an individual record for the phone call in Apollo.

parameters.name: user_id[]
parameters.description: Designate the caller in your team's Apollo account. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: contact_id
parameters.description: Designate the contact that was called. Use the Search for Contacts endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the contacts within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: account_id
parameters.description: Associate the call with an account. Use the Search for Accounts endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the accounts within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: to_number
parameters.description: The phone number that you dialed.

parameters.name: from_number
parameters.description: The phone number that dialed you.

parameters.name: status
parameters.description: The status of the phone call.

parameters.name: start_time
parameters.description: The time when the call started. Your entry should adhere to the ISO 8601 date-time format. Apollo uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) by default. If you do not account for time zone differences, you could add a start time that falls on a different day than you intended. The value you enter can either adhere to GMT, or you can adjust the time manually by specifying in hours and minutes how much you want to offset GMT.

parameters.name: end_time
parameters.description: The time when the call ended. Your entry should adhere to the ISO 8601 date-time format. Apollo uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) by default. If you do not account for time zone differences, you could add an end time that falls on a different day than you intended. The value you enter can either adhere to GMT, or you can adjust the time manually by specifying in hours and minutes how much you want to offset GMT.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The duration of the call in seconds. Do not enter minutes.

parameters.name: phone_call_purpose_id
parameters.description: Assign a call purpose to the record. Call purposes are unique to your team's Apollo account. When you use the Purpose search filter for calls in the Apollo product, you can find the corresponding call purpose ID in the URL.

parameters.name: phone_call_outcome_id
parameters.description: Assign a call outcome to the record. Call outcomes are unique to your team's Apollo account. When you use the Disposition search filter for calls in the Apollo product, you can find the corresponding call outcome ID in the URL.

parameters.name: note
parameters.description: Add a note to the call record.
parameters.example: This lead is interested in learning more about our new product line.

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required. Refer to Create API Keys documentation to learn how to create a master API key.

get.description: Use the Search for Calls endpoint to find calls that your team has made or received using the Apollo dialer. This endpoint requires a master API key. If you attempt to call the endpoint without a master key, you will receive a 403 response.

parameters.name: date_range[max]
parameters.description: Set the upper bound of the date range you want to search. Use this parameter in combination with the date_range[min] parameter. This date should fall after the date_range[min] date. The date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: date_range[min]
parameters.description: Set the lower bound of the date range you want to search. Use this parameter in combination with the date_range[max] parameter. This date should fall before the date_range[max] date. The date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD.

parameters.name: duration[max]
parameters.description: Set the upper bound for the call duration you want to search. The duration should be seconds, not minutes or hours. Use this parameter in combination with the duration[min] parameter. This number should be larger than duration[min].

parameters.name: duration[min]
parameters.description: Set the lower bound for the call duration you want to search. The duration should be seconds, not minutes or hours. Use this parameter in combination with the duration[max] parameter. This number should be smaller than duration[max].

parameters.name: inbound
parameters.description: Search for calls based on whether they were incoming (the prospect called your team) or outgoing (your team called the prospect).

parameters.name: user_ids[]
parameters.description: Find calls that included specific users in your team's Apollo account. You can add multiple users. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: contact_label_ids[]
parameters.description: Find calls that included specific contacts. You can add multiple contacts. In Apollo terminology, a contact is a person that your team has explicitly added to your database. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: phone_call_purpose_ids[]
parameters.description: Filter calls based on their purpose. Call purposes are unique to your team's Apollo account. When you use the Purpose search filter for calls in the Apollo product, you can find the corresponding call purpose ID in the URL.

parameters.name: phone_call_outcome_ids[]
parameters.description: Filter calls based on their outcome. Call outcomes are unique to your team's Apollo account. When you use the Disposition search filter for calls in the Apollo product, you can find the corresponding call outcome ID in the URL.

parameters.name: q_keywords
parameters.description: Add keywords to narrow the search of the calls in your team's Apollo account.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the Apollo data that you want to retrieve. Use this parameter in combination with the per_page parameter to make search results for navigable and improve the performance of the endpoint.

parameters.name: per_page
parameters.description: The number of search results that should be returned for each page. Limiting the number of results per page improves the endpoint's performance. Use the page parameter to search the different pages of data.

conversation_id.description: ID of the conversation associated with the call

count.description: Number of calls matching this facet

pipeline_total.description: Total number of calls in the pipeline

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required. Refer to Create API Keys documentation to learn how to create a master API key.

put.description: Use the Update Call Records endpoint to update your team's call records in Apollo. This endpoint requires a master API key. If you attempt to call the endpoint without a master key, you will receive a 403 response.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the call record to update

parameters.name: logged
parameters.description: Set to true if you want to create an individual record for the phone call in Apollo.

parameters.name: user_id[]
parameters.description: Designate the caller in your team's Apollo account. Use the Get a List of Users endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the users within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: contact_id
parameters.description: Designate the contact that was called. Use the Search for Contacts endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the contacts within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: account_id
parameters.description: Associate the call with an account. Use the Search for Accounts endpoint to retrieve IDs for all of the accounts within your Apollo account.

parameters.name: to_number
parameters.description: The phone number that you dialed.

parameters.name: from_number
parameters.description: The phone number that dialed you.

parameters.name: status
parameters.description: The status of the phone call. Possible values include: queued, ringing, in-progress, completed, no_answer, failed, busy

parameters.name: start_time
parameters.description: The time when the call started. Your entry should adhere to the ISO 8601 date-time format. Apollo uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) by default.

parameters.name: end_time
parameters.description: The time when the call ended. Your entry should adhere to the ISO 8601 date-time format. Apollo uses Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) by default.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The duration of the call in seconds. Do not enter minutes.

parameters.name: phone_call_purpose_id
parameters.description: Assign a call purpose to the record. Call purposes are unique to your team's Apollo account.

parameters.name: phone_call_outcome_id
parameters.description: Assign a call outcome to the record. Call outcomes are unique to your team's Apollo account.

parameters.name: note
parameters.description: Add a note to the call record.
parameters.example: This lead is interested in learning more about our new product line.

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required. Refer to Create API Keys documentation to learn how to create a master API key.

post.summary: View API Usage Stats and Rate Limits (Master key)

200.description: API usage statistics and rate limits for all endpoints

consumed.description: Number of requests consumed this hour
Number of requests consumed this minute

schema.description: Rate limiting information keyed by endpoint path and action

get.summary: Get a List of Users (Master key)

403.description: Master key required

get.summary: Get a List of Email Accounts (Master key)

200.description: List of email accounts with detailed configuration and deliverability information

id.description: Unique identifier for the email account

user_id.description: ID of the user who owns this email account

active.description: Whether the email account is active

default.description: Whether this is the default email account

seconds_delay_between_emails.description: Delay in seconds between sending emails

mailwarming_to_send_daily.description: Daily mail warming emails to send

get.summary: Get a List of All Custom Fields (Master key)
get.description: Retrieves a list of all custom fields in your Apollo account. This endpoint requires a master API key.

200.description: List of custom fields with detailed configuration

403.description: Forbidden - Master API key required. Refer to Create API Keys documentation to learn how to create a master API key.

typed_custom_fields.description: Add information to custom fields in Apollo. Your custom fields are unique to your team's Apollo account. This means that the examples in this documentation may not work for your testing purposes. To utilize this parameter successfully, call the Get a List of All Custom Fields endpoint and identify the id value for the custom field, as well as the appropriate data type. For example, if a custom field accepts picklist entries, you need to pass the accompanying id value for the picklist entry that you want to use as the input value.

label_names.description: Replace lists this contact belongs to. (Passing new values will overwrite existing lists.)

typed_custom_fields.description: Add information to custom fields in Apollo. Your custom fields are unique to your team's Apollo account. This means that the examples in this documentation may not work for your testing purposes. To utilize this parameter successfully, call the Get a List of All Custom Fields endpoint and identify the id value for the custom field, as well as the appropriate data type. For example, if a custom field accepts picklist entries, you need to pass the accompanying id value for the picklist entry that you want to use as the input value.

news_articles.title: Apollo.io Appoints Marcio Arnecke as CMO and Adam Carr as CRO to Accelerate AI-Powered Go-to-Market Innovation
news_articles.snippet: Apollo.io, a leading AI-powered go-to-market sales platform, today announced the appointments of Marcio Arnecke as Chief Marketing Officer (CMO) and Adam Carr as Chief Revenue Officer (CRO).
